Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Teflon Proteins for Protein-Protein Interaction Ligand Discovery
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division of NSF is funding Dr. William Pomerantz from the University of Minnesota to develop nuclear magnetic resonance methods of fluorine detection to study interactions between proteins. The research and educational goals in the Pomerantz lab address long-standing questions about biomolecular communications between proteins, drawing from findings in the disciplines of both chemistry and biology. Proteins termed transcription factors are the master regulators of cellular function. They facilitate the complicated transfer of information that specifies how the DNA code is used to make proteins. This research seeks to understand the details of the interactions between proteins and their underlying biology. The element fluorine will be used as a sensitive reporter for difficult-to-detect interactions at protein interfaces. This method is advantageous in view of fluorine's unique spectroscopic properties and its absence in natural biological molecules. Given the importance of transcription factors, this fluorine-based approach for studying protein-ligand interactions could significantly increase the repertoire of new protein targets for study and thereby open up avenues for improving the understanding of a wide variety of protein function. This project will include training for students with no prior experience of working at the chemistry/biology interface and will engage the Osher Life-Long Learning community's interests in science literacy and the role of chemical biology in science and technology.

This research project is focused on the development of fluorine nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) methods for detecting, quantifying, and defining novel modes of interactions at transcription factor-protein interfaces that include epigenetic regulatory proteins. Due to the enrichment of aromatic amino acids at protein-binding sites, multiple labeling strategies for sequence selective incorporation of fluorinated aromatic amino acids will be evaluated for reporting on protein binding interactions. The hyper-responsiveness of the fluorine nucleus to changes in chemical environment leads to simplified 1D-biomolecular NMR spectra that can be rapidly acquired and readily interpreted. This method will be evaluated against known ligands to characterize their mode of interaction and also in discovery format using small molecule libraries. These studies will be extended to acquiring mechanistic information under physiological conditions by in-cell fluorine-19 NMR. The origins of cellular uptake of fluorine-labeled peptide macrocylces will be investigated using lanthanide shift reagents for differentiating extracellular versus internalized peptides. This fluorine-19 NMR method will set the stage for use as a structure-based tool to find new chemical probes for challenging protein-protein interactions. Given the importance of transcription factors, the proposed fluorine-19 NMR approach to study protein-ligand interactions could significantly increase the repertoire of new protein targets opening up avenues for improving the understanding of their biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: My research program seeks to understand the details of protein-protein interactions (PPIs) with a focus on improving our knowledge of macromolecular recognition events. The broader impact of such findings will aid development of new medicines to significantly improve human health. Using 19F NMR, our unique contribution to this challenging field is our ability to develop new synthetic molecules to harmful PPI signaling events.

      Proteins are deemed undruggable if only low percentages of a broad array of drug-like molecules have been detected to bind using traditional biochemical and biophysical methods. To "drug the undruggable," we need new ways to identify protein-drug interactions and innovative chemical scaffolds that access new chemical space. My research program addresses the imperative for early-stage therapeutic development by harnessing the unique properties of fluorine incorporated at protein interfaces.  PPIs offer many new opportunities for discovering new biology and treating disease, but selective targeting with small organic molecules remains a grand challenge in the field. Taking a new perspective, my lab is using chemical biology tools to address this medicinal chemistry challenge.

    We have applied our approach towards transcription factors and proteins involved in epigenetics. Because protein-based 19F NMR enables us to understand the local environment around our fluorine tags, we can define not only if a molecule binds to a protein, but where, and can rapidly quantify the strength of the interaction. Fluorine's signal sensitivity, simplified spectra, minimal perturbation to protein function, and lack of biological background signals, make it a powerful NMR nucleus for accelerating ligand discovery. In support of this approach, my lab has developed new protein ligands through rational design of peptide macrocycles, fragment-based ligand screening, high-throughput screening, and medicinal chemistry optimization

 

      Given that transcription factors contribute to essential biological functions and the demand for structural methods to characterize them, our newly developed biomolecular 19F NMR approach for transcription factor-PPIs developed in this CAREER grant could significantly increase the repertoire of new targets, and open up new paths forward for small molecule discovery.

 

Intellectual Merit:  The NSF CAREER award laid the foundation of using protein-observed 19F NMR (PrOF NMR) for characterizing native protein binding sites, allosteric effects, and chemical probe development. My laboratory was the first to demonstrate the use of fluorinated proteins for small molecule screening by 19F NMR. We have since shown the compatibility of PrOF NMR for fragment-based ligand discovery, enhanced the speed of the method using paramagnetic additives, have provided methods for simultaneous labeling of proteins with multiple fluorinated amino acids, and have developed several new chemical probes for epigenetic proteins BPTF and BRD4. The former probe, S-AU1 was the the first reported inhibitor for BPTF.  The methods have been used in industrial settings in collaboration with Eli Lilly. Finally, despite over twenty years of study of the KIX domain of p300/CBP, we identified a previously uncharacterized ligand interaction site using PrOF NMR. Over the five years of this grant, successful demonstration of PrOF-NMR for ligand discovery has now been validated as a structure-based screening approach accessible for non-biomolecular-NMR experts and is enabling for finding lead compounds for challenging PPIs

     In summary, my laboratory has pioneered a new method and developed chemical tools for dissecting difficult transcription factor-PPIs. These studies lay the foundation for my lab's future work evaluating the function of transcription factor interactions involved in the epigenetic regulation of the cell.

Broader Impact: The research has supported two graduate students  and two postdocs.  The first postdoc started her independent career at Grand Valley State University and is continuing to use 19F NMR in her research.  Six undergraduates were trained on CAREER projects. They co-authored six papers supported by the CAREER grant. Four additional undergraduates worked on research related to this grant, but have not published.  The S-AU1 probe is the only inhibitor of the bromodomain motif of BPTF, this compound has been shared with researchers across the country for studying the functional effects of bromodomain inhibition in cell development and breast cancer, glioblastoma, and melanoma.  

 My educational goals in chemical biology are to expand chemical biology education to non-expert citizens and incoming graduate students new to working at the interface of chemistry and biology.  Through a collaborative project with the Osher Life Long Learning Institute, I developed a chemical biology short course for older adults.  As a parallel goal, I developed a two-week chemical biology "boot camp", exposing graduate students to experimental training complementing previous chemistry experiences.  To expand interest in biomolecular 19F NMR methods, I have been an invited speaker for our national Minnesota NMR workshop. Finally, with Prof. Scott Bur from Gustavus Adolphus College, we co-developed a course-based research experience (CURE) for an organic chemistry lab using PrOF NMR for analysis of new ligands for the KIX domain.  This research has progressed through three January-term sessions and has run for two full semesters.
